operation.descriptionCdata:
8e7dfd60-9f13-40eb-afe2-a70fff9a5e3e.0efb64cf-429f-46e0-bd49-102e42a2812c.prompt=Resource Name\: 8e7dfd60-9f13-40eb-afe2-a70fff9a5e3e.351865a8-d70b-460d-89d4-e3371c559ffe.prompt=Requested State\: 8e7dfd60-9f13-40eb-afe2-a70fff9a5e3e.b938bcf2-393e-450d-836c-69d47d0b5f5d.prompt=HostName\: 8e7dfd60-9f13-40eb-afe2-a70fff9a5e3e.description=
Changes the status of a cluster resource. A resource can be on one of the following 2 states\: online or offline. This operation can be used to turn a resource online or offline.

Inputs\:
host - the hostname or ip address of the cluster server.
resource - the name of the resource to change the state for. If the resource doesn't exist, a corresponding message will be returned and the operation will fail. 
state - the requested state for the resource. The only possible values here are online and offline. Any other value will result in a failure with a corresponding message.

Primary output\:
returnResult - a string containing the state the resource is in after executing the operation -Online or Offline-, if the operation succeeds, or a relevant message if the operation fails - for example\: "invalidState is an invalid state for a resource. The only valid values are online and offline"-.

Responses\:
success - the clustered resource is in the requested state
failure - the clustered resource is not in the request state. Other reasons for failure are\: invalid cluster IP/hostname; non-existing resource; invalid requested state. 

Notes\:
1. Thanks to MS's way of building the COM interface to MS Clustering admin tools, we can't use any impersonation with it.  
Therefore, to make it work properly you have to run the Windows RAS service as an account with privileges.
2. Clean install of Windows 2008 (on the RAS machine) does not include by default msclus.dll library. To work around this issue there are 2 alternatives. The first one is to install the failover clustering feature on the machine, which will install the msclus.dll to "%systemroot%\system32\msclus.dll". The alternative is to  copy "%systemroot%\system32\msclus.dll" from a Windows Server 2003 server to the same location on the Windows 2008 (R2) machine and run "regsvr32 %systemroot%\system32\msclus.dll" (if you have a 64-bit Windows 2008 then you have to copy msclus.dll from a 64-bit Windows 2003).
3. To administer a Windows 2008 cluster you have to install RAS on a Windows 2008 machine. Backward compatibility has been broken by Microsoft, according to http\://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb756975.aspx, which means that you cannot call Cluster APIs from a Windows Server 2008 Cluster to a down-level cluster (Windows NT 4.0, Windows 2000, or Windows 2003). Also, you cannot be on a down-level client and remotely call Cluster APIs against a Windows Server 2008 node.
operation.name: Change Clustered Resource Status
